articles.headline: Russia Skips Hybrids in Push for Cars Using Natural Gas
articles.snippet: Russia, the world’s second-largest producer of natural gas, is making a bet that methane-powered cars are an alluring market for future growth.
articles.abstract: Russia, the world’s second-largest producer of natural gas, is making a bet that methane-powered cars are an alluring market for future growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Igor A. Samarsky of the southern Russian city of Krasnodar gets fuel economy on his 1998 Lada sedan that would make a Prius owner green with environmental envy.

articles.headline: Never Mind Facebook; Winklevoss Twins Rule in Digital Money
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley and Wall Street are taking note of bitcoin, which has drawn prominent investors like the Winklevoss twins.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley and Wall Street are taking note of bitcoin, which has drawn prominent investors like the Winklevoss twins.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler — Olympic rowers, nemeses of Mark Zuckerberg — are laying claim to a new title: bitcoin moguls.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Ex-KPMG Partner Is Charged in Insider Case
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors revealed a brazen two-year insider trading scheme involving Scott London, a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG, and a longtime friend.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors revealed a brazen two-year insider trading scheme involving Scott London, a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG, and a longtime friend.

articles.headline: Pentagon Finds Nuclear Strides by North Korea
articles.snippet: A defense intelligence report concluded with “moderate confidence” that the North has learned to make a small but unreliable  warhead.
articles.abstract: A defense intelligence report concluded with “moderate confidence” that the North has learned to make a small but unreliable  warhead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new assessment by the Pentagon’s intelligence arm has concluded for the first time, with “moderate confidence,” that North Korea has learned how to make a nuclear weapon small enough to be delivered by a ballistic missile.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Tech Firms Push to Hire More Workers From Abroad
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley is battling in Washington to make the immigration process easier for people with skills coveted by the technology sector.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley is battling in Washington to make the immigration process easier for people with skills coveted by the technology sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Vishal Sankhla, an Indian engineer, is among those at the center of a storm over how to fix the nation’s immigration system.

articles.headline: A Plot Twist at Herbalife Draws in the Auditors
articles.snippet: Herbalife’s next auditor will be watched closely by the participants in a stock fight being waged by hedge funds.
articles.abstract: Herbalife’s next auditor will be watched closely by the participants in a stock fight being waged by hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Herbalife, which describes itself as a global nutrition company, and which critics deride as a purveyor of overpriced products that is really a pyramid scheme preying on naïve people with dreams of easy wealth, has already provided one of the best stock market dramas in years. Now, through no fault of its own, it could become a catalyst for change in the auditing profession.

articles.headline: In Gun Debate, No Rift on Better Care for Mentally Ill
articles.snippet: Lawmakers have been working across party lines on legislation advocates say could help keep killers like the gunman in Newtown, Conn., from slipping through the cracks.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers have been working across party lines on legislation advocates say could help keep killers like the gunman in Newtown, Conn., from slipping through the cracks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the Senate has been consumed with a divisive debate over expanded background checks for gun buyers, lawmakers have been quietly working across party lines on legislation that advocates say could help prevent killers like Adam Lanza, the gunman in the Newtown, Conn., massacre, from slipping through the cracks.
